Class Timer

java.lang.Object
  Timer

public class Timer
extends java.lang.Object

A very simply Timer class that functions as a virtual stopwatch. This can be used as a semi-accurate method of measuring the elapsed time while some code is running. It can be used as a timer in a game, or to track the efficiency of some procedure. Methods for stop, start and reset allow easy control of Timer objects. Methods are included that return seconds (as an int), milliseconds (as a float) or a formatted String.

Version:
v1.0.2
Author:
Jordan Cohen

Constructor Detail

Timer

public Timer()
Constructor does nothing... however, I avoided making this class static so that multiple Timers could be used simultaneously.

Method Detail

endTimer

public void endTimer()
Stop the Timer

getTimeInMilliseconds

public float getTimeInMilliseconds()
Return the elapsed time in seconds. This assumes that the timer has already been started and stopped (but not reset). This will return the value as a float and is most useful for shorter durations where second is not accurate enough.

Returns:
float The number of milliseconds elapsed, as a float.

getTimeInPreciseSeconds

public float getTimeInPreciseSeconds()
Return the elapsed time in seconds. This assumes that the timer has already been started and stopped (but not reset). For very short durations, this will return zero even though some time has elapsed.

Returns:
float The number of seconds elapsed, as an int.

getTimeInSeconds

public int getTimeInSeconds()
Return the elapsed time in seconds. This assumes that the timer has already been started and stopped (but not reset). For very short durations, this will return zero even though some time has elapsed.

Returns:
int The number of seconds elapsed, as an int.

getTimeString

public java.lang.String getTimeString()
Returns elapsed time as a neatly formatted String. Most practical for applications where output (rather than calculation) is the goal. The exact format will depend on the time elapsed - either ms, sec, or min:sec.

Returns:
String neatly formatted display of time elapsed

resetTimer

public void resetTimer()
Reset the Timer

startTimer

public void startTimer()
Start the Timer
